dialogue so this is a this is a working session so if you're here to do your
email have a snooze keep the rain off you might not be in the right place this
is a working session on a critical issue which we're calling the social progress
challenge what is the social progress challenge the challenge is that our
world is working on a broken model economic growth has delivered enormous
benefits for Humanity over the last 50 years in particular but we know there's
a problem despite economic growth we can see in this country how millions of
Americans are living lives of frustration and desperation reflected in the politics that we're seeing in my
country in the United Kingdom the economy is growing unemployment Sarlo at the lowest levels historically but still
we're seeing social indicators of flatlining people are frustrated the same story is true across the rest of
Europe it's true across China across India across South Africa across Mexico
we've got a problem which is that we've got a world oriented towards progress based solely around economic growth but
we know that economic growth is not delivering for people it's the challenge
of what people often talk about as inclusive growth and don't take my word for it take the word over the chair of
our advisory board Michael Porter of Harvard Business School Michael Porter is the world's leading guru on economic
competitiveness he is a business professor he's a preferred expert on strategy he's
a red-blooded capitalist he is a registered Republican but he still thinks that our model for economic
growth alone is not enough and we've got to figure out ways to turn our wealth into real well-being more effectively
and the social Progress Index which my organization is working on is an effort
to address that challenge the social Progress Index has been designed not as a replacement for GDP and measures of
econ my growth but as a compliment it's designed to sit on alongside and to look
at the real things that matter to real people you'll see here the model we've used for the social Progress Index it's
asking fundamentally three questions about a society first of all does everyone have the
basic needs of survival food water shelter safety secondly does everyone
have those building blocks of a better life education information health and a
good quality environment and finally does every individual have the opportunity to pursue their hopes and
dreams with rights with freedom of choice freedom from discrimination and access to the world's most advanced
knowledge this is an independent measure of whether we're living in a good society fundamentally it's got four
design principles the first really important to note is it's got no economic indicators not because we think
the economy doesn't matter but because if we can create a measure of social progress independent of economic
measures we can then look at the relationship between the two to understand what is this thing inclusive
growth secondly we've based the index on indicators that are all about inker
outcomes we take all the data from the UN and other trusted sources it's all secondary data and when we bring it
together a whole range of indicators to measure outcomes so we're not measuring how much a country spends on health care
we're measuring the health outcomes they achieve we're not measuring whether countries passed laws against
discrimination we're measuring whether people experience discrimination so that way we try to strip out value judgments
about which of the right policies and get beyond some of the politics thirdly we've made it relevant to all countries
too much of our measurement in the world has sort of two lenses one for the rich world one for the poor world when
actually what countries are in Crete increasingly facing common challenges so we've created a measure that can be
relevant across all countries and critically fourth we created something that's actionable because we're not here
in the index building business just for the fun of it we're in this business because we really want to change the world critically and
I was really pleased when I ride my registration on the first day to be invited to take a pin for check for the
SDGs and certainly for us the social Progress Index is a tool which is aligned with sustainable development
goals is a tool that's seeking to support the implementation of sustainable development goals so what
we've been doing is we've be able to measure about a hundred and twenty-eight countries in the world on their social progress and we can put them all
together create an aggregate score out of 100 and rank the countries in how they perform we'd be doing it for a few
years now and here is the 2017 ranking now you'll see at the top we have
Denmark and at the bottom we have Central African Republic and I'd like to
say this is reassuringly boring if we had Central African Republic at the top and Denmark at the bottom we would be
doing something wrong so we can then go down and see how we go from Denmark and go through the rankings and seeing how
different countries perform now this is one way of looking at the data but I will just show a different way of
looking at the data which is not just looking at their absolute performance but looking at how countries perform
compared to their GDP and that's here so here's social progress on the
vertical axis higher is better GDP per capita on the right hand of the horizontal scale further to the right is
more and what we see first of all in for some reason I've lost my regression line on this but the general pattern is that
yes economic growth is associated with higher social progress and that's good
news the model we've had is not completely flawed that's why we've seen economic growth is lifted a billion
people out of poverty in the last 20 years economic growth has real potential to benefit people it can help us build
roads it can pay for nurses it can pay for vaccines it can pay for teachers there's lots that economic resources can
do to improve our lives but it's not the whole story there's plenty of noise around the trendline that you can't see
that shows that GDP simply is not destiny at every level of GDP there are
opportunities for more social progress risks of less some countries are really

country that's not so good at turning its wealth into real quality of life where citizens I'm sad to say the United
States so the United States this is all bit complicated so the headline thing is all of our country's 128 countries the
u.s. is the fifth highest in GDP per capita but the u.s. is only the 18th in
our ranking on social progress it's in the second tier of performance of social progress behind European countries
behind Canada behind Japan the u.s. is really underperforming on social
progress but what the scorecard do is it compares how the u.s. is performing across this range of indicators against

heavyweight like the u.s. to other economic super heavyweights and you can see the countries listed there on the

mark a blue mark if it's underperforming a red mark and as you see this scorecards got a lot of red on it
the US is the only major industrial country that consistently underperforms
on its social progress relative to GDP per capita we've seen as consistently since 2014 when we first did this if we
want to see what is ailing people and making people angry in America it's
right here then it's hearing things like you know safety it's here in the education system
it's there in health health care America spends more than any other country in

and Swit since 2014 this has been flatlining so I've got a scorecard like

into GDP others not so good like the US now this is all very interesting but
what's this gonna do to actually change what occurring in people's lives well the
first one we want to do is really create this rigorous understanding between economic development and social progress
and really demonstrate this point empirically that if you're basing your society's development on economic growth
alone you've got only half a model so that's the first thing we want to do is really
nail down that issue secondly it helps us put all the different issues of
society faces into a common framework and see where the biggest problems are and also looking at that both in
absolute terms but relative to other countries of similar wealth thirdly by
creating this common measure it creates a common language that can bring different sectors together around
discussing where are the biggest problems where are the solutions bringing government business and civil

apply it to sub-national level as well so this is why we created the social Progress Index as a tool to help us
change the model for development for our societies and what we've been doing over the last four years is working in a
number of countries to do this we started in Latin America and what we've been doing there is now spanning a dozen
countries I've got a few examples here maybe your staff in the middle Paraguay
is a country that's experienced decades of economic growth without social progress so they were actually the first
country in the world to adopt social Progress Index as an official metric for their country so they now have a
national development plan with two targets an economic growth target and a
social program progress target and that means that social progress is now cascading through their government
budget system setting priorities and one of the priorities they've set based on this is around eliminating child
malnutrition by 2018 and so more money is going into those programs and so yeah
we like to believe that we've played a role in helping ensure that fewer children in Paraguay are going to bed
hungry which is why we're doing this I mentioned sub-national indices we've
done work in Colombia working measuring social progress across 10 different cities looking at trends of social
progress over that period and in Bogota we've looked at different districts of the city and is now being used by city authorities to
set their development plans we've also collaborated as you'll see at the bottom with coca-cola and the Brazilian
cosmetics company Natura on community social progress indices for specific communities in the Amazon region of
Brazil that those companies are interested in for supply chain reasons to help support the development of those
specific communities so we've got a measure that goes from the world countries States cities districts even
down to community level the social Progress Index is flexible at any kind of scale after Latin America with them
we've done we started work in Europe and so the social Progress Index has now been adopted by the European Commission
and one of their big priorities is what they call cohesion which is bringing together these disparate countries some
very rich like your Sweden's and Denmark's some very poor like Bulgaria
or Romania and try to bring them together through a whole programme of regional investments this is a program
worth more than a hundred billion dollars and they've been using GDP to allocate resources and to decide where
the programs are they have now adopted and using social Progress Index to inform those programs programs and
start to bring a new way of thinking about how those monies can be used in just a couple of months ago I was in
Ireland where the the Finance Minister holds an annual national economic dialogue which brings together
government business civil society trade unions to talk about the next year's
budget priorities and that traditionally this discussion begins with a presentation of the macroeconomic
situation Ireland this year it started with the presentation on the macroeconomic situation and the social
progress situation and by really putting people's real quality of life at the center of the debate the central
discussion we're hoping that this can really drive change in how budgets realloc resources are used so Europe is
one of our big pilot a big area that's adopted in now and then most recently we're now working in India so that's 1.2
billion people and the government of India Prime Minister Modi's government has got a big agenda around the
